Text: I most certainly do because it kind of just laid out the format as to how things have been done, in regards to gender, previously, and how things are being done now. So it almost gives you like a format as to what to expect, and then also to know your personal rights, as being a female.

Name: Maria
Text: My professor just stated the fact that women aren't in technology, and then he listed the races, and then when he said Spanish people aren't that...There are not that many Spanish people in technology. He looked at me, and then that was that. He just kind of listed the facts and went on and said, “Okay.”

Name: Maria
Text: Yeah, he was saying statistics. He was doing a lecture, and he just read off all the statistics.

Name: Laura
Text: I think it's there if you seek it out. For example, I'm interested in this, and I came to this focus group today, but I'm sure that you could get through the four or five years of the major without it really coming up. We were kind of hopeful it would come up in the ethics class, and it very much didn't.

Name: Maria
Text: Personally, when I told my family I'm doing this, it's kind of like, you know, "You shouldn't be doing it. It's boring."

Name: Laura
Text: So the first one is that I've noticed that I think women tend to have higher expectations or higher requirements for staying than men do. So if you're not kind of at the top of the class, you'll think you're not good enough. Then the other thing is just harassment. I know something I've struggled with a lot over the past year is, "Do I want to go into this industry and be surrounded by dudes for the rest of my life?" Actually it didn't kind of come up for any of the other questions. I was stalked by a fellow student at one point, and then that caused a whole bunch of social issues. So if you're gonna be experiencing that in your career, it's very easy to be forced out.

Name: Jessica
Text: Sure. Absolutely. So I believe that women are underrepresented because...I think it starts usually at home. Usually I think that women play a role in the household, and I think that kind of rolls over into their career sometimes. It's more like female-appropriate, if you will, careers, and then it's more like male-appropriate careers. For some reason, technology seems to be more male-based than female-based. I think that women usually stray from anything technology. If you're putting together a shelf, usually women don't want to do that, or fixing a car. Usually men do that. So I think for that reason alone, possibly.

Name: Maria
Text: I would say yes, but I would also say you have to find that support. It's not just gonna come just because you're in the same class or just because you say, "Want to start a study group?" And then nothing happens. You have to really look and see who's asking questions, who's not asking questions, who has all the notes. Also, being a...sharing your notes if you have someone that you know is struggling with them. Try and help them.

Name: Marie
Text: Because I noticed that guys...They do like to interact with each other in my class, and they're open to just forming study groups, but I noticed that no one really approaches me. So I haven't really had the courage to approach anyone yet because I haven't made any acquaintances. So I just study alone.

Name: Laura
Text: I'd say the groups tend to focus on one or two people that are kind of getting it. So everybody knows who they are. They'll attract a group of people and kind of do kind of studying, kind of tutoring.

Name: Jessica
Text: I just hang around people that's like way smarter than me. I figure like...

Name: Maria
Text: For the overall UMBC community, I think CWIT could have a stronger presence. It already has a strong presence.

Name: Maria
Text: Oh, I really like the workshops that you guys do. I think that helps people who aren't in the program and just reaching out and just talking to students about the program.

Name: Marie
Text: I feel like I haven't heard that much about CWIT and SWE here than I have with IEEE and ACM and all of these other male-dominated clubs. I feel like it would be nice if all of those science organizations somehow collaborate with each other and host large events together that includes, like, all STEM majors and people outside of that major. But other than that, I usually see people just make their own small groups and kind of distance themselves away from other people. Yeah.

Name: Laura
Text: I would suggest some mentorship between older and younger students. I kind of didn't realize I was lacking as a younger student, but I think that at this point, I would have a lot to offer a young woman entering the major.

Name: Maria
Text: I think that, with IS, lots of people don't like it because it's too broad, but I think that the broadness gives it a little bit more useful...You're a little bit more useful with your skills. Like, you can do web development. You can do networking. You can do business, if that was your focus. So I think maybe keeping it multi-functional degree.

Name: Jessica
Text: Math.

Name: Laura
Text: I want to jump off that. Most, if not all, of the professors, in the 300-400 level of classes, at some point, end up saying, "Now you've all taken linear algebra. Haven't you?" It is not required for the major, and nobody's taken it because nobody has extra time, and it's a serious problem.

Name: Jessica
Text: Can I add a serious topic? I would...I think that, specifically with the math courses, I understand like we have the classroom time. But if there were a very serious curriculum that one can take in addition to the math course itself...I understand we have the math lab, but sometimes it's kind of like lackadaisical, and it's not really as serious. I think that maybe if a professor were to sit in, maybe even in the math lab, as an instructor, it could assist, because sometimes the peer-to-peer is great, but I think that maybe a professor may be more beneficial.

Name: Maria
Text: Mine is the opposite of...Not what you said. But mine is the opposite, whereas the IS major is really broad. But I would change the specialization that you get in that area. If you really did want to do...Maybe have a freshman course where you can pick your path and see exactly which ones you want to choose because sometimes you can't do them all. I mean you can't do them all, but it's probably better to, you know, have a really specialized skill by the time you get out, in just one certain area. With math, I think also maybe finding different ways to teach students math, instead of just saying, "It's hard," and, "You have to work hard," which is what I get with a lot of professors.

Name: Maria
Text: Yeah, and making tutors...Making known that tutors are there is probably a big one too. I had one for accounting, and I didn't know he was there the whole time.

Name: Marie
Text: Yeah, I'm not too familiar with the course catalog, but it would be nice if courses like that can help students kind of explore what majors they want to enter in, because I know like...I think I've had three or four friends who decided to change into computer science after they took the non-major course. So yeah.

Name: Betty
Text: I had done a little bit of computer IT work in high school because my high school had a program. And then I was between chemical engineering and computer engineering. And actually in my interview for CWIT, Dr. LaBerge, after talking to him, he was like, "No, you definitely need to do computer engineering," and I agreed. So I kind of went that route because I like to see how things work way below the gate, besides just the digital logic and whatnot.

Name: Kevin
Text: There are some stereotypes about CompSci majors that we're all awkward and have poor hygiene, I guess. We're kind of shy and quiet. And a lot of times, it's kind of true. I mean, everyone…awkward and dirty is not really as true as everyone says it is. But for the most part, it seems like most of my peers are more introverted.

Name: Betty
Text: I'd say for me, it's assumed that a lot of them are males. If you gain a list of people, I won't be the first person somebody asks, "Oh, do you know anything about computers?" Also, I'd say people don't really know what CompE is. The amount of times I'll just get, "Oh, so you're coding?" I'm like, "Not really." I mean, we do, but it's only like half of it. So that's a big confusion. But then I do know there's also some stigma around the CompE program here that it can be a little rough here. That's what I've heard from my peers. And I agree, but the outside perspective is reassuring. Yeah.

Name: Betty
Text: Well, in mine…so my senior year or my senior class, there are upper 50s, 60 of us and there is me and three other girls. So it's very, very little.

Name: Betty
Text: Not really, actually.  (on female students sticking together)

Name: Jeffrey
Text: Yeah, I noticed there aren't that many females in my computer science classes as well. And, yeah, it's very male-dominated and I think with computer science, if you pick that major and you're in the 300 or 400-level courses, you're expected to be good. You’re expected to be a good programmer and both looking in from the people who are in the major and the people who are outside of the major, they expect you to be good with computers and good at programming.

Name: Jeffrey
Text: The professors. I think they expect you to be good at math. Science, I don't think so because there's a whole bio field. There's a whole science field. So yeah.

Name: Kevin
Text: I've noticed that most people who go into CompSci, they tend to have a more logical way of thinking so they tend to be better at math than, say, English majors, I guess. Maybe it's just their personalities.

Name: Betty
Text: I don't know. I know for us, a big thing is you have to be really resilient. I mean, depending on the teachers you get in CompE, you either get teachers that are going to be not too bad, the class is still kind of bad, or you get teachers that mentally wear you down. We've had a lot of people just leave because they're like, "I can't do it anymore because of the low grades that are given in CompE." But then they curve, but they don't tell you they're going to curve. So it's stressful. So I've noticed that if you've gone through it, you've got some mental stamina. And they generally have to be good at math. Science too because we do go into chemistry in the hardware aspects. A little. Very little. And besides that, we all have our different things. We all do very different things. So besides those base things that kind of throw us all together, we all have our different personalities.

Name: Jeffrey
Text: I feel like it may be biased, but I've noticed that for the very select few, other than for the very select few, a typical computer science student would be good at programming. And so their computer science classes are pretty easy for them. And they aren't involved much around campus. So they have a lot of free time to do coding on their own or to work on the projects that, for the very select few who are really involved, they either struggle or don't have as much time as some students. And then the teachers sort of teach for those students who have a lot less time to do other things. Yeah. So that the class moves either faster or projects are harder. And so the typical student, I'd say, is going to class and then that's about it.

Name: Isaiah
Text: I would say things are different for me because, in my 201 and my 202 CompSci class, a lot of students I see spend a lot of time in the computer lab getting help from the TAs. And I know a lot of friends who are CompSci and CompE majors who are in different clubs, like HackUMBC and the Game Developers’ club.

Name: Kevin
Text: Yeah, I think I'm kind of biased too just because I tend to hang around HackUMBC people. I'm actually friends with the president of it. And him and a few of my other friends, we have a bunch of side projects going on so we tend to have a little bit more experience, I guess. And experience translates to doing better in the classes, I suppose. So it's hard to relate, I guess, when people are like, "Oh, it took me three weeks to get this project done." We're like, "We ran into all these problems before so we know how to fix it." But usually, I think everyone's pretty helpful in CompSci, though, because I've never seen anyone who's refused to help another student who needed help.

Name: Jeffrey
Text: Yeah, I really agree with that. A lot of the typical students have experience before. So that also might contribute to them doing really well in classes because they've…they're involved with other technical clubs and stuff.

Name: Kevin
Text: I enjoy what I do. I don't really…I don't associate myself as a CompSci major. I mean, I just am. Maybe it's because I'm a commuter student. I don't live on campus. I'm not as involved in campus activities or group projects as I could be. Most of what I do is outside of school and not school-related. So maybe that plays into it some.

Name: Betty
Text: I have to say I know in my year, we have a fair amount of students that are commuters or came back after taking a break after high school or whatnot. So a lot of them are older so they're all at different phases in their lives. But as far as me, I know it took a while to adjust because I know I was that girl in CompE that it took a while to earn respect. But I feel like by the end, and I’ve talked with Dr. LaBerge and we both agreed that I'm respected there now amongst most people. But right now, I feel like none of us really do that much outside of school because we all have a lot to do. But we all band together and we're there for help or support when you have to rant or whatnot. I feel like I have a group of peers that check in on you or whatnot. So it feels like you're in there. You're not alone in your major.

Name: Jeffrey
Text: Well, like I said about my biased vision of a typical student, I don't think I'm one of those typical students since I don't…I'm either not involved in technical clubs so I haven’t been able to get experience outside of class and I also don't have a lot of free time to dedicate to side projects and my in-class projects as much as I'd like. And I’m not very good at math. And yeah. I always struggle in all my CompSci classes. So it's always a struggle and it's never easy as it seems like for most people.

Name: Isaiah
Text: I guess I kind of fit in. I fit in a little bit more than last semester because I'm getting better at programming. The first time I programmed was in my 201 class so I didn't know programming as well as other people did. And since I got the experience from 201, my 202 class isn't as hard as it is for most people, I guess.

Name: Kevin
Text: A lot of all-nighters.  (on the major)

Name: Jeffrey
Text: I'd add in supportive.  (the major)

Name: Kevin
Text: Most of my support comes from my friend group. We all kind of teach each other new concepts and help each other fix bugs or get through a particularly tough problem. I've learned a lot through them. And actually, I feel like I've learned more working through them, either on school projects or side projects, than I have through the actual classes themselves.

Name: Betty
Text: I think for me, it's been Dr. LaBerge. He kind of took me under his wing after I interviewed. And I had health things and whatnot that came up that made my experience as a student a little abnormal, but he always made sure to give me the advice from his years of experience, how to best address when I go into a class, let them know about health issues. He also was there to reassure me if I'm like, "Man, this class is just…I have no idea what's going on," to be like, "Don't worry. I get this all the time." So then I know I'm like, "Okay. I know it's not just me feeling like this or struggling." And then over time, I think as people came out of their shells more, you learn that you're not the only one really struggling. Or that some people seem like they are really great and you find out they're like, "No, I have no idea." But yeah, Dr. LaBerge has been a big…he's helped me through every step.

Name: Isaiah
Text: I would say friends and teachers really help. One teacher specifically, my CompE 212 teacher, when I went to talk to him one time, he told me that in the major, exam grades will be low and stuff so don't really worry about grades, worry about understanding concepts.

Name: Betty
Text: So for me, I know it's pretty…because I've had this conversation with peers and whatnot. Being a girl, I come in and the stereotype seems to be that if you're a girl in CompE, you're doing something to get your way through. It's like you're going to go suck up to the teacher or you're not actually smart enough so you're leeching off of someone else. And there are people that I see that do kind of leech off of people. And either it eventually falls out for them or they can maintain it through. And then, there are some people that do go and suck up to every single teacher. But there are guys that too do that, but it's more noticed that girls will.

Name: Betty
Text: So when I came into CompE, I was never the person…like if there was somebody sitting next to me and I worked on a project with them, even if I did that whole part of the project, they would…somebody would come up and ask them the question and then they'd respond like they did it. And I'd have to interrupt and go, "No, no, no, no. Tell me, what did you do?" And go through and it took time. But now, I think by junior year, I started to feel like I was pretty much respected amongst everybody. Senior year, it's definitely like…there are still a few that'll make a comment or two there, like, "Why don't you go suck up to the teacher," or…

Name: Betty
Text: But it's also hard when you have occasional students that do go suck up or leech off of other people so then it makes it hard. But overall, people come to me with questions now. There are still some times where I'm just completely overlooked. Or I still notice a lot there are times when I'm overlooked or in capstone where I'll be the one getting held with the documentation. Yeah. But it's sort of like you have to…in order to earn respect as a girl, you have to prove. There is a constant, "You must prove that you were there," for…you were meant to be there through exam grades and whatnot. And if you're a guy, there's a lot less pressure. For some, there's going to be people that have to prove. But most of the time, it's pretty accepted that you know what you're doing.

Name: Kevin
Text: I've definitely heard it. I haven't personally experienced it. I think it's really sad just because most of the women that I've known in my STEM classes, I don't want to say they've been smarter, but they've been able to hold their own better than most of the guys in the class. So I think it's kind of ridiculous that they need to prove themselves. And it's probably true. It's…I don't know. I don't know why people can't just get over and treat each other as people.

Name: Betty
Text: I should mention, too, it's happened with teachers too. I've had teacher issues.

Name: Kevin
Text: I feel respected. It’s never been something I've worried about, though.

Name: Isaiah
Text: Yeah, I don't feel disrespected, so…

Name: Kevin
Text: Yeah. A lot of my peers, I think, are pretty competitive.

Name: Betty
Text: I'd say we have a few that are really always going to try to…they're always there, trying to one-up anybody else. But for the most part, we just generally all know that we're going to get low grades or whatnot. So we all are like, "You know what, guys? If we all study and we all know this stuff, we're fine. As long as we all band." It's like if we all don't know it, if we all do bad, we do well, type of mentality. So there are not huge amounts trying to show off. But there are some. There are some people that are.

Name: Kevin
Text: In my experience, they tend to ignore them a little bit more.

Name: Jeffrey
Text: I'd say it depends. There are some who blatantly show off because of their character and there are others where it's very subtle, especially for the students who pick it up. They're like, "Wait, I have no idea what that person just said." But the professor may understand it and respond to it, but it may not seem like they're showing off.

Name: Betty
Text: Yes. We have one particular teacher who's a very big put-down for a lot of people. Just in general, he'll make statements about, "I don't know how you made it this far. Why are you even in CompE?" And it's said in a harsh tone. There was also an incident with that teacher with him being very harsh on women. I actually just thought maybe I did something wrong and I was trying to figure out what. But then my fellow peers came up and noticed it too that he was being extra harsh if I answered a question wrong. It would be like, "What were you thinking? How could this even be?" Or if even a part of it was wrong, then if a male student answered a part of it wrong, he'd be like, "It's not exactly right."

Name: Kevin
Text: When I said ignored earlier, it wasn't completely, it was more, "I'm going to focus my lecture on everybody else." Just because maybe the teacher feels like the rest of the class needs it more than this particular person and everyone else would get more out of the lecture than that person will. So that's what I was referring to.

Name: Kevin
Text: It was more like, "Stop answering every question, then. Let other people answer." Because when one person answers, it's kind of annoying for the entire group, I think.

Name: Kevin
Text: No, because I think being a man in computer science is pretty accepted. In STEM in general, I think, it's probably more male-dominated. So if you say you were a CompSci major or someone reads that you're a CompSci major, they'll assume you're a man.

Name: Kevin
Text: They probably would. (on people assuming a CS major is a white man)

Name: Kevin
Text: I notice a lot of racial diversity in my classes, though. I don't know if that's been your experience or maybe I'm just…

Name: Betty
Text: There are a lot of white people in my CompE class. I'm not even going to lie. There are…we don't have…we have a few…well, I guess it's like Arabian and those…East…Middle Eastern? A few. Yeah. It's a lot. I don't know. It gets a little better, I think, as we go down. But it also gets a little better with women in some other classes. Still not great, but there are a lot of white people in my graduating class, that are CompEs.

Name: Kevin
Text: But I wonder if that's an issue, though. Maybe it's just that's what they're interested in and the other groups aren't interested in it.

Name: Kevin
Text: Do you need the racial diversity? I think we do. I'm just wondering.

Name: Betty
Text: The thing I will note, though, is CompE graduates, there are very few…there are a lot less white students in the grad program. So I think that's intriguing. You get a lot more foreign people coming in.

Name: Jeffrey
Text: I think that race isn't seen as an issue, like you aren't really judged by your race. But if the classes were more diverse, which I've noticed that they aren't…it's a lot of white people as well. I might be able to…or other people might be able to see more in common or have a lot more in common and the professor might be able to teach the class at a much-preferred pace.

Name: Jeffrey
Text: Just everyone in my classes seems very competent. And I'm not going to blame their race for it, but they just seem like…their education just seems very…

Name: Betty
Text: And I know I've noticed I'm very willing to talk to professors or whatnot. So it's kind of made me better with going about and not being afraid of talking to people higher up than me. And my internships that I've had, I was placed in an odd position very high up toward the top of the structure. And so it's really got me a lot of networking experience and the skills I've learned here, with presenting and everything, prepared me to lead along with my personality type of thing. Yeah.

Name: Kevin
Text: Actually, this summer, me and a few friends were planning on working on a startup so we're hoping that that'll do something. I don't know. We'll see. I think it's a lot easier to start your own business in CompSci as opposed to CompE just because, I mean, you can just make a website, get it online, and you have it. Whereas with CompE, you need more hardware and it needs more funding.

Name: Betty
Text: I will say, too, through CWIT, when they have us do our StrengthsQuest at the beginning, and even though it gets repetitive, but going through that every year has been helpful because when I go into interviews and they ask me, "How would you handle a situation when one person is lacking?” It really makes you look at the strengths they do have. That was a big experience on my leadership skills, actually.

Name: Jeffrey
Text: I would definitely say CWIT has helped me to get to where I am. I don't know where I'd be without CWIT. So I definitely put a lot of credit and contribution toward that resource because I think it's very valuable.

Name: Betty
Text: With CWIT, I had…in my year, there are no other computer engineering people so I'm alone in that aspect. But it did help me make friends with someone who graduated last year and develop a good relationship with them. So now they work at the same place I do. So that's kind of kept going and I'm able to get advice from them. And I feel like even though it might have been better if I had someone in my year, that's still worked out really well. We did have classes together and now I'm able to pass along my knowledge down the line.

Name: Isaiah
Text: I don't know a lot of organizations on campus that could really help because I'm a freshman. But the things that help me the most are my clubs and the CompSci TA lab downstairs.

Name: Isaiah
Text: My Game Development Club because it has a bunch of people who have programming experience. So that helps, talking to them.

Name: Betty
Text: Ours really depend on the class. Sometimes with CompE, they really drill it into you to be careful when you're working together with people. And so working together on some projects is…you're kind of terrified that they're going to find something, even if it's something little. It's not always like that, but like I said, a lot of people commute. So living on campus and as commuters, it's hard for us to all get together. But there are some classes where we all definitely do let go and we'll just go in ITE and study. But I've also never been the biggest study group person because I'm a very visual person, but when I do need help, there are always people around that study.

Name: Kevin
Text: I think…no. Well, with CompSci you can have issues with plagiarism if everyone's working on the same project, but I haven't run into it.

Name: Jeffrey
Text: I think that the CS department doesn't really teach students how to work in groups. And everyone's always like, "You're going to be working in teams when you get to the real world. But here, you don't want to cheat off each other so you've got to work separate." But even in the real world, you're sort of coding alone, but working together on the same thing. You're sort of like separate but together. And when you are given a group project, the rare times that you are in computer science, you don't really know how to work together. And you sort of end up just working along and then compiling all the work, I guess, which is similar to the industry, but I don't know if that's very helpful. I don't know if that's considered group work.

Name: Kevin
Text: No, I just think it would be good if they taught more collaboration skills in class because if everyone's working on the same thing, you can have conflicts where you need to figure out what’s right and what’s wrong, take this piece from this and this piece from that, if he said, "I'm working on this and you work on this part," then the process goes a lot more smoothly.

Name: Jeffrey
Text: In the introductory CompSci courses, they really stress that we don't work together to prevent cheating. But I didn't care. And I made my groups in the first three computer science courses. And sure, if it wasn't for them, I wouldn't have been able to be where I am now, but that's what really has helped me learn and it's really what made me feel I fit into that major. So what's really made me happy about being in the major was working together and seeing everyone talk about the project and share, bounce ideas off of each other. That's one of the few things I really, really, really like about this major and working in groups.

Name: Betty
Text: CompE has you do a few group projects where you’re paired up using the same equipment and whatnot, and you have lab partners. And through all that, I think it gives you a good experience. You get a lot of group work and you learn about when you have issues with people, how to go about handling them. Sometimes, those issues happen and they just float there. But it definitely gives you an idea when you're going into an environment, what you have to do if there's a team member that's slacking.

Name: Betty
Text: It's also, working in capstone, it's also given me the fact that I kept saying, "Give me actual work. Give me actual work," and they would just kind of hoard it. So it's taught me what things I should not do in the industry, like hoard my work and just keep it to myself when other people should be helping. And then I would get stuck with, like I said, writing papers a lot. Which people don't realize how many you've written. So then they go, "Well, you're not doing anything." That can be frustrating. But overall, I feel like the group dynamics that they have you do with lab partners and whatnot, it really teaches you to work with others and how to go about that.

Name: Jeffrey
Text: I've been thinking about this for a little bit and I kind of just said it, but really teaching how to work in groups and working in groups. I think they scare students too much when it comes to plagiarism.

Name: Betty
Text: Yes. And just using common sense not to copy word for word from other students, but really learning how to collaborate on projects really helps them learn, helps them succeed. It's what helped me succeed. And if it wasn't for going against the rules, I wouldn't have learned as much as I did from other students because we all have different backgrounds. We all have different things to contribute. And we all learn different things from the same lecture. So it was very important that we work together and share those ideas outside of the classroom.

Name: Betty
Text: Yeah, I agree. There needs to be…because in the work environment, even if you are working together but coding separately, you still can go and ask for help on different aspects, I've realized. And that here, if you do that, it's like, "Nope, nope, nope. You took that one idea."

Name: Betty
Text: We have one and it's integrated into our CompE 349, which is our pre-capstone and our capstone. So we've had that. We have little scenarios that occur. They go through scenarios of whatnot. But as far as going off of plagiarism, it's obvious. Like, "Okay. Don't copy and paste and then not give any credit." But they've shown us in the work world, there are going to be times where it's like, "Why would you go and waste the company's time doing this when you could go Google something, find a solution that's there?" Especially if it's something simple like that. They address that and it's always been amazing to me that that's not there. But then the ethics mostly taught us to speak up if we see that there’s something going wrong. But yeah. They don't go into too much detail on, I think, gender, class, race things. I think that would be an area that would be interesting to see if they'd improve on, just to help people because then it helps your managerial skills.

Name: Kevin
